page.title: 05MINSTER ABBEY
page.content: Minster Abbey,situated in the eastern part of Minster,dates back to 674 AD when it was built by Lady Sexburger, queen of Kent.Lady Sexburger,a widow ruled for nearly a decade until her son reached the age of 15,whereupon she abdicated,keeping only a small piece of land in the centre of Sheppey.Upon this land she built,near a Roman temple,the small Benedictine Abbey.It took 30 years to build, with the only labourers being 77 women.The nuns who occupied the Abbey were great healers and many of the herbs they used have been proven today.However, the Abbey is not the same as it was,as Viking damage was repaired by the Normans using a different stone,and a fire in Elizabeth I's reign caused great destruction.In 1982 the Abbey Gatehouse was opened as a small museum for Sheppey artefacts. Laurence Hayes.
